case_name: Controller of Estate Duty v. Smt. Parvathi Ammal

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1395 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1395 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 4th March 1969 of Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 215 of 1965 and Referred No. 109 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 4th March 1969 of the Madras High Court- in Tax Case No. 215 of 1965 and Referred No. 109 of 1965.

facts.text: Shri R. Venkateswara Iyer died on April 6, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The matter arises out of the estate duty case of Shri R. Venkateswara Iyer who died on April 6, 1957.

facts.text: Smt. Parvathi Ammal is the widow of the deceased and accountable person.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Smt. Parvathi Ammal who is the widow of the deceased and is an accountable person in the case,

facts.text: Assistant Controller determined principal value of estate as Rs. 2,50,374 including Rs. 1,50,000 for Mayavaram Lodge.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Controller determined the principal value of the estate to be Rs. 2,50,374. In computing the principal value the Assistant Controller took into account a sum of Rs. 1,50,000 on account of the value of property known as Mayavaram Lodge.

facts.text: Till March 11, 1955 deceased owned two buildings including Mayavaram Lodge and some agricultural land.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Controller found that till March 11, 1955 the deceased, who was a self-made man, owned two buildings, including Mayavaram Lodge, besides some agricultural land.

facts.text: Deceased carried on boarding and lodging business in Mayavaram Lodge and small chit business.

anchor.surface_text: The deceased was carrying on the business of boarding and lodging in Mayavaram Lodge. He had also a small chit business.

facts.text: On March 11, 1955 deceased executed a document described as partition deed giving Mayavaram Lodge to five sons in equal shares, retained other house and agricultural land.

anchor.surface_text: On March 11, 1955 the deceased executed a document described as a partition deed, whereby he gave Mayavaram Lodge, to his five sons in equal shares and retained for himself the other house and agricultural land.

facts.text: On June 25, 1955 deceased entered into lease agreement with sons for Mayavaram Lodge and continued boarding and lodging business.

anchor.surface_text: On June 25, 1955 the deceased entered into an agreement with his sons by which they leased to the deceased Mayavaram Lodge wherein as before he continued to carry on his boarding and lodging business.

facts.text: In profit and loss account Rs. 15,000 mentioned for rent of Mayavaram Lodge.

anchor.surface_text: In the profit and loss account a sum of Rs. 15,000 was mentioned for payment of rent of Mayavaram Lodge.

facts.text: Deceased later gave boarding house on sub-lease to a third party.

anchor.surface_text: Later on, the deceased gave the boarding house on sub-lease to a third party.

facts.text: Respondent claimed Mayavaram Lodge excluded as transferred more than two years before death.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed that Mayavaram Lodge should be excluded from the estate duty assessment of the deceased on the ground that the said property was transferred on March 11, 1955 more than two years before his death.

facts.text: Assistant Controller found property self-acquired, deed is settlement not partition.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Controller rejected these contentions. He found that the property referred to in the deed dated March 11, 1955 was the self acquired property of the deceased and that there was no evidence to show that the deceased treated it as joint family property.

facts.text: Deceased took back property on lease shortly after settlement, rent by book entries.

anchor.surface_text: Although the settlement was found to have been made by the deceased more than two years before his death, the fact that the deceased took back the property from his sons shortly thereafter to continue his business therein showed,

facts.text: Board of Direct Taxes found deed registered on June 29, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Board found that the deed, though executed on March 11, 1955 more than two years prior to the death of the deceased, was registered only on June 29, 1955.

facts.text: Madras High Court answered question partly in favour of assessee and partly revenue.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by the Controller of Estate Duty on certificate is against the judgment of the Madras High Court whereby that court answered the following question referred to it under section 64(1) of the Estate Duty Act, 1953 ... partly in favour of the assessee and partly in favour of the revenue

facts.text: High Court held only value of right to possession and enjoyment as lessee passes.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that it is only the value of the right to possession and enjoyment in the hands of the deceased as a lessee that would pass on his death and would attract duty.

facts.text: Supreme Court held entire value of Mayavaram Lodge liable under section 10.

anchor.surface_text: Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death.

facts.text: Deceased was competent to dispose of property at death under section 6.

anchor.surface_text: According to section 6, property which the deceased was at the time of his death competent to dispose of shall be deemed to pass on his death.

facts.text: Lease on June 25, 1955 meant donees did not retain possession to exclusion of donor.

anchor.surface_text: On June 25, 1955 the donor took the aforesaid house on lease from the donees. These facts would show that the possession and enjoyment of Mayavaram Lodge was not subsequent to the gift retained by the donees to the entire exclusion of the donor

facts.text: Property gifted was entirety of Mayavaram Lodge with all rights.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court has found that the property which was the subject-matter of the gift under the deed of March 11, 1955 was the entirety of Mayavaram Lodge with all the rights
question referred to it under section 64 1  of the Estate Duty Act, 1953  Act 34 of 1953   hereinafter referred to as the Act  partly in favour

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge or any portion of its value is liable to be included in the principal value of the Estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death?

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge or any portion of its value is liable to be included in the principal value of the Estate of the deceased as property deemed

issues.text: Whether the document dated March 11, 1955 constituted a deed of partition of joint family properties or a settlement of self-acquired property of the deceased

anchor.surface_text: Plea was also taken that the document of March 11, 1955 constituted deed of partition of joint family properties. The Assistant Controller rejected these contentions. He found that the property referred to in the deed dated March 11, 1955 was the self

issues.text: Whether the gift of Mayavaram Lodge became effective on the date of execution (March 11, 1955) or the date of registration (June 29, 1955) for the purposes of section 9 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The Board found that the deed, though executed on March 11, 1955 more than two years prior to the death of the deceased, was registered only on June 29, 1955. According to the Board, the gift of Mayavaram Lodge became effective only on June 29,

issues.text: Whether the donees bona fide assumed possession and enjoyment of Mayavaram Lodge immediately upon the gift and retained it thenceforward to the entire exclusion of the donor or of any benefit to him by contract or otherwise under section 10 of the Act, and if so, whether the entire property or only a portion passes

anchor.surface_text: therefore, estate duty was payable in respect of that property under section 10 of the Act. ... the donee must bona fide have assumed possession and enjoyment of the property, which is the subject-matter of the gift,

arguments.claim: s10 requires donee assume immediate bona fide possession and retain to exclusion of donor or benefit by contract or otherwise; both cumulative

anchor.surface_text: The section must be grammatically construed as follows Property taken under any gift, whenever made,... The crux of the section lies in two parts 1 the donee must bona fide have assumed possession and enjoyment of the property,... 2 the donee must have retained such possession and enjoyment of the property to the entire exclusion of the donor or of any benefit to him, by contract or otherwise. Both these conditions are cumulative.

arguments.claim: 'Otherwise' in s10 ejusdem generis, means legal obligation enforceable at law or equity

anchor.surface_text: The word otherwise should be construed ejusdem generis and should be, interpreted to mean some kind of legal obligation or some transaction enforceable at law or in equity which though not in the form of a contract, may confer a benefit on the donor.

arguments.claim: Facts show donees did not retain possession and enjoyment to exclusion due to lease back on June 25, 1955

anchor.surface_text: On June 25, 1955 the donor took the aforesaid house on lease from the donees. These facts would show that the possession and enjoyment of Mayavaram Lodge was not subsequent to the gift retained by the donees to the entire exclusion of the donor

arguments.claim: Entire value of Mayavaram Lodge liable under s10

anchor.surface_text: Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death.

arguments.claim: Remand needed to determine if deed was partition

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it has been argued on behalf of the respondent that we should remand the case to find as to whether the deed of March 11, 1955 constituted deed of partition.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e case of Rash Mohan Chatterjee  supra  to which we have already made a reference, the stand taken on behalf of the respondent cannot be accepted in t

arguments.court_reasoning: Board found self-acquired, no evidence joint family

arguments.claim: s10 deems entire gifted property to pass, not just lessee right; rejects proportionate view

anchor.surface_text: The view urged on behalf of the respondent and accepted by the High Court that the estate duty is payable only in respect of the value of the right to possession and enjoyment in the hand of the deceased as a lessee of Mayavaram Lodge runs, in our opinion, counter to the plain language of section 10 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Precedent in George Da Costa supports entire property liable under s10

anchor.surface_text: Unless each of these conditions is satisfied, the property would be liable to estate duty under section 10 of the Act see George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore, supra.

arguments.claim: Distinguishes Ramachandra Gounder as gifted property was shorn of tenancy rights

anchor.surface_text: The case of Ramachandra Gounder supra upon which great reliance has been placed by Mr. Swaminathan can hardly be of much assistance to him because in that case the gifted property was subject to the tenancy-at-will granted to the firm

holdings.text: on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death

anchor.surface_text: Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Donees did not bona fide assume possession immediately and retain to entire exclusion of donor due to lease-back on June 25, 1955; section 10 deems entire gifted property (entirety of Mayavaram Lodge) to pass; rejects High Court's proportionate lessee right view as contrary to plain language

holdings.text: the possession and enjoyment of Mayavaram Lodge was not subsequent to the gift retained by the donees to the entire exclusion of the donor or of any benefit to him by contract or otherwise

anchor.surface_text: On June 25, 1955 the donor took the aforesaid house on lease from the donees. These facts would show that the possession and enjoyment of Mayavaram Lodge was not subsequent to the gift retained by the donees to the entire exclusion of the donor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show donor took lease shortly after gift execution/registration, continued business, paid rent by book entries; fails second limb of s10 test

holdings.text: the view urged on behalf of the respondent and accepted by the High Court that the estate duty is payable only in respect of the value of the right to possession and enjoyment in the hand of the deceased as a lessee of Mayavaram Lodge runs counter to the plain language of section 10 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The view urged on behalf of the respondent and accepted by the High Court that the estate duty is payable only in respect of the value of the right to possession and enjoyment in the hand of the deceased as a lessee of Mayavaram Lodge runs, in our opinion, counter to the plain language of section 10 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s10 deems the property taken under gift to pass if conditions not met, not merely the benefit/right retained by donor; 'to the extent' qualifies partial non-exclusion, but here entire non-exclusion failure; George Da Costa precedent

holdings.text: the said document was not a partition deed relating to the joint family property

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Board came to the conclusion that the said document was not a partition deed relating to the joint family property. In the circumstances, we find no sufficient ground for remanding the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board found properties self-acquired, no evidence deceased treated as joint family or waived separate rights; Assistant Controller/Board findings accepted, no remand

holdings.text: Both these conditions are cumulative. Unless each of these conditions is satisfied, the property would be liable to estate duty under section 10 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: the donee must have retained such possession and enjoyment of the property to the entire exclusion of the donor or of any benefit to him, by contract or otherwise. Both these conditions are cumulative. Unless each of these conditions is satisfied, the property would be liable to estate duty under section 10 of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grammatical construction of s10: (1) immediate bona fide assumption by donee; (2) retention to exclusion or no benefit; both required; George Da Costa

holdings.text: The word otherwise should be construed ejusdem generis and should be, interpreted to mean some kind of legal obligation or some transaction enforceable at law or in equity which though not in the form of a contract, may confer a benefit on the donor

anchor.surface_text: The word otherwise should be construed ejusdem generis and should be, interpreted to mean some kind of legal obligation or some transaction enforceable at law or in equity which though not in the form of a contract, may confer a benefit on the donor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second limb of s10: exclusion from property and from benefit by contract or otherwise; 'otherwise' ejusdem generis with contract, i.e., enforceable obligation; but first limb independent, no need for legal basis for possession

holdings.text: we find no sufficient ground for remanding the case

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we find no sufficient ground for remanding the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower findings on self-acquired nature and no joint family evidence sufficient; High Court proceeded on gift assumption

holdings.text: the amendment brought about by the Finance Act, 1965 by inserting second proviso to section 10... was not retrospective

anchor.surface_text: The amendment brought about by the Finance Act, 1965 by inserting second proviso to section 10, as observed by this Court in the case of George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore, was not retrospective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-amendment s10 applies to 1957 death; follows George Da Costa

precedents.citation: Y. S. Mani v. Controller of Estate Duty 1

anchor.surface_text: Y. S. Mani v. Controller of Estate Duty 1  wherein it had held that to the extent to which the donor retains an interest in the entirety of the property given away by him as gift, there will be pro tanto liability to estate duty.

precedents.case_name: Y.S. Mani v. Controller of Estate Duty
precedents.cited_proposition: to the extent to which the donor retains an interest in the entirety of the property given away by him as gift, there will be pro tanto liability to estate duty

precedents.citation: George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore 1

anchor.surface_text: as observed by this Court in the case of George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore 1 , was not retrospective. The said section would consequently have to be construed for the purpose of this case which relates to, the estate, of the deceased who died on April 6, 1957, as it stood before the amendment.

precedents.case_name: George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: the amendment brought about by the Finance Act, 1965 by inserting second proviso to section 10, was not retrospective

precedents.citation: George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore, supra

anchor.surface_text: under section 10 of the Act  see George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore, supra . The second part of the section, as observed in the above mentioned case, has two limbs the deceased must be entirely excluded,  i  from the, property and  ii  from any benefit by contract or otherwise.

precedents.case_name: George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: the second part of section 10 has two limbs: exclusion from property and from benefit by contract or otherwise

precedents.citation: John Lang Ors. Thomas Prout Webb 1

anchor.surface_text: The object underlying a provision like section 10 of the Act was explained by Issacs J. in the case of John Lang Ors. Thomas Prout Webb 1  decided by the High Court of Australia in 1912 in the following words

precedents.case_name: John Lang v. Thomas Prout Webb
precedents.cited_proposition: object of provisions like section 10 is to avoid inconvenience in ascertaining genuineness of gifts by fixing standards consistent with genuineness but prima facie indicating colourable attempts to escape duty
precedents.cited_holding: lease back even at full rent prevents entire exclusion of donor

precedents.citation: Clifford John Chick Anr. v. companymissioner of Stamp Duties 1

anchor.surface_text: The Above reasoning of Issacs J. was approved by the Judicial Committee in the case of Clifford John Chick Anr. v. companymissioner of Stamp Duties 1  wherein the judicial Committee dealt with a case under section 102 of the New South Wales Stamp Duties Act, 192056.

precedents.case_name: Clifford John Chick v. Commissioner of Stamp Duties
precedents.cited_proposition: donor not entirely excluded if retains possession/enjoyment even under independent commercial arrangement with full consideration; single fact is exclusion from subject-matter
precedents.cited_holding: partnership agreement allowing donor possession meant no entire exclusion

precedents.citation: H. R. Munro ors. v. Commissioner of Stamp Duties, 1

anchor.surface_text: This principle can be illustrated by reference to two cases, one decided by the Judicial Committee in 1933 and the other by this Court in 1973. The Judicial Committees decision is in the case of H. R. Munro ors. v. Commissioner of Stamp Duties, 1

precedents.case_name: H.R. Munro v. Commissioner of Stamp Duties
precedents.cited_proposition: when property gifted is shorn of partnership rights, donees assume possession of what is gifted (land minus partnership rights), benefit to donor referable to partnership not gift
precedents.cited_holding: transferred land subject to prior partnership agreement excluded from duty

precedents.citation: Controller of Estate Duty Madras v. C. R. RamaChandra Gounder. 2

anchor.surface_text: while that of this Court is in the case of Controller of Estate Duty Madras v. C. R. RamaChandra Gounder. 2  In the case of H. R. precedents.case_name: Controller of Estate Duty Madras v. C.R. Ramachandra Gounder
precedents.cited_proposition: benefit as partner not referable to gift if property gifted subject to existing tenancy to firm
precedents.cited_holding: house let to firm before gift and amounts credited to sons not deemed to pass under s.10

precedents.citation: Commissioner for Stamp Duties of New South Wales v. Perpetual Trustees Company Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: We may mention some of the other cases to which reference has been made by Mr. Swaminathan during the course of arguments. The case of Commissioner for Stamp Duties of New South Wales v. Perpetual Trustees Company Ltd. 1  related to an indenture of settlement made between the settlor

precedents.case_name: Commissioner for Stamp Duties of New South Wales v. Perpetual Trustees Company Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: donee assumed possession of gifted equitable interest in shares
precedents.cited_holding: settlement shares to trustees for son on majority; son had contingent interest, assumed possession thereof

precedents.citation: St. Aubyn Ors. v. Attorney General 1

anchor.surface_text: The case of St. Aubyn Ors. v. Attorney General 1  related to certain properties held on trusts and their dispositions. It is not necessary to set out the long chain of facts of that case suffice it to say that there is nothing in that case which runs counter to the view we are taking in the matter.

precedents.citation: Controller of Estate Duty v. R. Kanakasabai Ors.  2

anchor.surface_text: In Controller of Estate Duty v. R. Kanakasabai Ors.  2  the ,deceased executed in June 1951 separate deeds in favour of his sons, grandsons, daughter and wife, settling properties thereby severally in favour of the respective beneficiaries absolutely and with full power of alienation.

precedents.case_name: Controller of Estate Duty v. R. Kanakasabai
precedents.cited_proposition: benefit must be referable to gifted property; unenforceable hopes or provisions not charged on property do not attract s.10
precedents.cited_holding: no interest reserved; provisions not charged on property

precedents.citation: Rash Mohan Chatterjee Ors. v. Controller of Estate Duty West Bengal.  1

anchor.surface_text: An illustration of this is furnished by the case of Rash Mohan Chatterjee Ors. v. Controller of Estate Duty West Bengal.  1   1   1964  52 I.T.R. 1  Estate Duty part . In that ease the deceased settled on July 1, 1954 certain premises in trust

precedents.case_name: Rashmohan Chatterjee v. Controller of Estate Duty West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: where donor leases back part of gifted premises, duty on that portion under 'to the extent'
precedents.cited_holding: duty only on leased portion occupied by deceased

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the case of Rash Mohan Chatterjee  supra  to which we have already made a reference, the stand taken on behalf of the respondent cannot be accepted in the face of the decision of this Court in the case of George Da Costa  supra .

precedents.case_name: George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: entire gifted house included where donor continued to occupy till death despite gift and possession to donees
precedents.cited_holding: value of house included under s.10

anchor.surface_text: The case of Ramachandra Gounder  supra  upon which great reliance has been placed by Mr. Swaminathan can hardly be of much assistance to him because in that case the gifted property was subject to the tenancy-at-will granted to the firm Ramachandra Gounders case was thus covered by the principle laid down in Munros case.

precedents.case_name: Controller of Estate Duty Madras v. C.R. Ramachandra Gounder

anchor.surface_text: The present case, in our opinion, clearly falls within the purview of the dictum laid down by the High Court of Australia in the case of John Lang  supra  and of the Judicial Committee in the case of John Chick  supra .

precedents.case_name: John Lang v. Thomas Prout Webb
precedents.cited_proposition: falls within purview where donor not excluded

anchor.surface_text: the case of John Lang  supra  and of the Judicial Committee in the case of John Chick  supra . As already mentioned, the High Court has found that the property which was the subject-matter of the gift under the deed of March 11, 1955 was the entirety of Mayavaram Lodge with all the rights

precedents.case_name: Clifford John Chick v. Commissioner of Stamp Duties
precedents.cited_proposition: falls within purview where donor not excluded

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the above we accept the appeal, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it and answer that question in favour of the revenue and against the accountable person. Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death. The appellant shall be entitled to the costs of the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal accepted; High Court answer discharged; question answered fully in favour of revenue holding the entire value of Mayavaram Lodge liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death.
directions: discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it
answer that question in favour of the revenue and against the accountable person
The appellant shall be entitled to the costs of the appeal

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the above we accept the appeal, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it and answer that question in favour of the revenue and against the accountable person. Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death. The appellant shall be entitled to the costs of the appeal.

As a result of the above we accept the appeal, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it and answer that question in favour of the revenue and against the accountable person. Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death. The appellant shall be entitled to the costs of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The view urged on behalf of the respondent and accepted by the High Court that the estate duty is payable only in respect of the value of the right to possession and enjoyment in the hand of the deceased as a lessee of Mayavaram Lodge runs, in our opinion, counter to the plain language of section 10 of the Act.

As a result of the above we accept the appeal, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it and answer that question in favour of the revenue and against the accountable person. Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death. The appellant shall be entitled to the costs of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Board came to the conclusion that the said document was not a partition deed relating to the joint family property. In the circumstances, we find no sufficient ground for remanding the case.

As a result of the above we accept the appeal, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it and answer that question in favour of the revenue and against the accountable person. Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death. The appellant shall be entitled to the costs of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: the donee must have retained such possession and enjoyment of the property to the entire exclusion of the donor or of any benefit to him, by contract or otherwise. Both these conditions are cumulative. Unless each of these conditions is satisfied, the property would be liable to estate duty under section 10 of the Act

As a result of the above we accept the appeal, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it and answer that question in favour of the revenue and against the accountable person. Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death. The appellant shall be entitled to the costs of the appeal.
the sole and free right to deal with it as he might think fit. Each of the three partners owned a pr

edges.explanation: Holding h6 interprets 'otherwise' ejusdem generis as legal obligation enforceable at law or equity, supporting the precise meaning of the exclusion condition in the bona fide possession test c14

anchor.surface_text: ased to the deceased himself on a rent of Rs. 150 per month for a term of five years with effect from the date of settlement. The lease expired on Jun

edges.explanation: Interpretation of 'otherwise' in h6 as ejusdem generis legal obligation supports h2's finding on lack of exclusion by contract or otherwise

anchor.surface_text: the sole and free right to deal with it as he might think fit. Each of the three partners owned a property, that of the donee son being that which had

edges.explanation: Holding h6 on construction of 'otherwise' addresses the phrase in issue i4 concerning exclusion of benefit by contract or otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The word otherwise should be construed ejusdem generis and should be, interpreted to mean some kind of legal obligation or some transaction enforceable at law or in equity which though not in the form of a contract, may confer a benefit on the donor.

As a result of the above we accept the appeal, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it and answer that question in favour of the revenue and against the accountable person. Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death. The appellant shall be entitled to the costs of the appeal.
In the circumstances, we find no sufficient ground for remanding the case.

As a result of the above we accept the appeal, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it and answer that question in favour of the revenue and against the accountable person. Our answer is that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge is liable to be included in the principal value of the estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death. The appellant shall be entitled to the costs of the appeal.
